The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. The present paper provides a categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators. This addresses a question about the foundations of quantum theory raised in these programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasitic animals that are of great interest because of their extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. We have generated genomic and transcriptomic assemblies for two distantly related species of myxozoans and compared these to the genome and transcriptome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the cnidarians and that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal level. In addition, we find that myxozoans lack key elements of signaling pathways and transcriptional factors important for multicellular development. These results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This is the first time to our knowledge that a taxonomic sampling that represents the breadth of myxozoan diversity has been used to infer the evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa. This study provides a unique perspective on the evolution of the Myxozoa and the origin of parasitism. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that the SARS-CoV-2 accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear translocation of the transcription factors STAT1 and STAT2, which are key players in the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1, which is a key factor in the docking of the cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex. Our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a deeper understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and provides a potential target for the development of new antiviral strategies. The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1 dimer. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. This study is of interest to the general public because it describes a mechanism of action for a drug target that is used in the treatment of cancer.

Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to predict the impact of climate change on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level food-plant consumption. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species of wild and domestic large mammals in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of % grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that large mammal diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This may have important implications for the management of large mammal populations and the conservation of biodiversity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis, and many are financially fragile. We also assess the impact of the CARES Act loans relative to grants. Our results suggest that grants are more effective at increasing business resilience than loans. However, the CARES Act is likely to be a critical source of funding for many businesses.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The solar system is the only place in the universe where we can study the origin of the solar system. The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources. The results highlight the need for effective management of the global fishing fleet.

The ability to increase the number of offspring produced by a single female is a defining characteristic of all species. In this study, we show that the ability to provide for offspring, either directly or indirectly, is a strong predictor of reproductive output. We find that the ability to provide for offspring, either directly or indirectly, is a strong predictor of reproductive output. The greatest increase in reproductive output we observe is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of the domestication process and the evolution of allonursing in humans. Our results suggest that the ability to provide for offspring is a key factor in the evolution of domestication.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, a form of the protein that is known to be neurotoxic. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA by limiting the accumulation of α-syn. This would be of great importance, as no treatment is currently available to slow down the aggressive neurodegenerative process in MSA. This study also opens the door to the development of new therapeutic strategies for other synucleinopathies.

The vascular endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform their functions. The endothelium is able to control the function of the blood vessels by receiving and integrating information from multiple sources. The information is integrated and coordinated by a network of cells. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, and to be efficient in the transmission of information. The design of the network is important for the control of the vascular system.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the targets of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for the allosteric communication between these two domains. We have shown that this residue is essential for the C-type inactivation gating and that its mutation leads to an inversion of the allosteric coupling. Finally, we have provided a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a molecular explanation for the functional inversion of the allosteric coupling and opens the way for the development of new drugs.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood, and the potential of the microbiome to be manipulated therapeutically is being explored. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is constantly changing in response to the host and the environment. The ability to manipulate the microbiome in a controlled manner is an important tool for the treatment of disease and the study of host–microbiome interactions. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are a component of the gut microbiome, are capable of synthesizing natural products that could be used to manipulate the microbiome. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi could be a source of natural products that could be used to manipulate the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior and is often associated with a low probability to become dominant. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a low probability to become dominant, directly influences social dominance in rats and that this effect is mediated by the brain region the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. These findings may also have implications for the understanding of the social behavior of humans.

The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design space is restricted by the material properties and structural patterns. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. The strategy is based on the inverse design of composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct properties. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The strategy can also be extended to design structures with complex and navigable responses. This work provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. It is expected to have a significant impact on the development of mechanical devices.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a downstream element of the let-7 pathway and that it is expressed in the fetal period and not in the adult. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of adult hemoglobin expression and that it is a key factor in the reprogramming of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid cells. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis protects cancer cells from ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This resistance is mediated by the induction of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we found that SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis is required for the ferroptosis-suppressing activity of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling in cancer cells. Finally, we showed that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide a rationale for the development of new therapies for cancer, which are effective against both the tumor and its microenvironment. (Show more)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are used in the majority of patients with hypertension. However, the long-term use of these drugs is associated with a higher risk of adverse effects. Our study shows that the most common drugs in this class activate the Ca2+ signaling pathway in vascular smooth muscle cells, which leads to the up-regulation of the Ca2+ channel ORAI and the activation of the Ca2+ channel ORAI. This study provides a mechanism for the adverse effects of these drugs and suggests that the use of these drugs should be limited in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of older forest bird populations, but the recovery of these species has been slow. The NWFP has also failed to halt the decline of early-seral bird populations, which are associated with the loss of early-seral ecosystems. These findings underscore the need to continue to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

We present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on the prediction of the solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity of acylide antibiotics. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been shown to be effective in many image-processing problems. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters and with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is based on a simple set of operations that can be easily implemented, trained, and applied in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results for several segmentation problems with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is also easier to extend to more complex problems. The code for the proposed architecture is available at https://github.com/y-s-s/deep-dense.git.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This practice has been shown to suppress melatonin, phase-shift the biological clock, and reduce sleep quality. The present study shows that this practice also reduces the amount of sleep and the quality of the following night’s sleep. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediment and/or magnetic grains/microspherules collected from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the 2- to 5-mm diameter spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YDB cooling.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial, and its function in the development of autoimmunity is not fully understood. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, and its function is not limited to the control of T cell activation. We found that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity in both the thymus and periphery.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification, and a dataset of 154 genomes or transcriptomes to trace the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved previously controversial beetle relationships, dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous, and supported the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms. Moreover, plant cell wall-degrading enzymes (PCWDEs) obtained from bacteria and fungi via horizontal gene transfers may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of PCWDEs encoded in their genomes. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapeutics for the treatment of COVID-19. This work also provides a proof of concept for the application of deep learning in the optimization of other protein molecules.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of great interest to evolutionary psychologists. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. We also found that the amount of C1q protein accumulation in hippocampus, which may represent the accumulation of senescent synapses with enhanced vulnerability to complement-mediated degeneration, is highly dependent on APOE alleles. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the evolution of the Earth. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. The inner core nucleation paradox is a contradiction between the required degree of undercooling and the stability of the inner core phase. We show that the bcc phase has a higher nucleation rate than the hcp phase, which reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation. This two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core provides a key factor in solving the paradox. Our results also suggest that the inner core is likely to be the first solid core in the solar system. This is the first time that the inner core is considered to be the first solid core in the solar system.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that the brain responses to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA), are blunted in marijuana abusers, who also have higher levels of negative emotionality and addiction severity. These findings suggest that the blunted responses to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors.

Language is the only known cognitive skill that evolved in isolation from other animals. This makes it a unique window into the evolution of the human mind. Here we use a powerful new approach to link brain and language data across many models and many datasets. We find that the most accurate models predict nearly 100% of the variance in neural responses to sentences and generalize across different datasets and imaging modalities. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the evolution of language may have been driven by the evolution of predictive processing. This view is supported by the fact that the same models also predict brain responses to nonlinguistic stimuli.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that the training of DL models is unstable, even though the universal approximation theorem guarantees that any function can be approximated arbitrarily well. We show that this instability is due to the fact that there are problems in scientific computing where there is no algorithm that can compute a stable neural network (NN) with a given accuracy. We introduce a new class of algorithms, called fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This result is a step toward the development of a theory of stability for neural networks.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a case study in the failure of science communication. The pandemic is a perfect example of how the public is misinformed about the nature of science and the role of scientists. The public is often led to believe that scientists are the ones who come up with the answers to the world’s problems. This is not true. Scientists are the ones who ask the questions. They are the ones who study the data. They are the ones who come up with the hypotheses. And it is up to the rest of us to decide whether or not to believe the answers they come up with.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae, which infects the peripheral nerves, and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which causes the more severe and less understood lepromatous leprosy. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two bacteria are very similar, and that the differences are likely to be the result of natural selection. The results suggest that the two bacteria have been evolving together for thousands of years, and that they are still very similar. This is important for understanding the evolution of the disease and the development of new treatments. (Show more)

The evolution of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a fundamental question in the field of quantum information and statistical mechanics. It is also of great practical relevance for quantum simulation of quantum many-body systems, which is a promising avenue for the development of quantum technologies. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. Our result is based on a combination of integrability and quasiparticle descriptions of the entanglement dynamics. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain and find excellent agreement with numerical data. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide range of quantum many-body systems.

This study describes the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is the only one in clinical development. The vaccine is highly attenuated, and the only difference between it and the wild-type virus is the presence of 283 silent mutations. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is protective in hamsters, and the only difference between the vaccine and the wild-type virus is the presence of 283 silent mutations. This study provides a proof of concept for the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The vaccine is the only one that can be used for mass vaccination, and it is the only one that can be used in the future. This study provides a solution to the global pandemic. The study also provides a solution to the problem of the lack of a vaccine for the next pandemic. The study provides a solution to the problem of the lack of a vaccine for the next pandemic.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown. Here, we develop a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for understanding the role of ectoparasites in future outbreaks.

The brain is the most complex organ in the human body. It is also the most plastic, allowing us to learn and adapt to our environment. The evolution of the brain is therefore a key factor in the evolution of intelligence. The brain is a highly complex organ, and it is difficult to compare the brains of different species. This study uses a new method to compare the brains of different species by counting the number of neurons in each brain. The results show that the brains of reptiles are much smaller than those of birds and mammals, but the number of neurons in reptiles is much lower than in birds and mammals. This suggests that the evolution of the brain is not a simple process of increasing brain size.

The role of TRAP1 in cancer has been controversial. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a molecular explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled by proteins that control their length and stability. One of these proteins is cofilin, which is responsible for the disassembly of actin filaments. However, cofilin is also able to sever actin filaments. We show that the action of cofilin is enhanced in the presence of mechanical stress. We also show that the mechanical stress can be used to enhance the severing of actin filaments. This is important for cells, because the severing of filaments is a key process for the regulation of many cellular processes. Our results have implications for our understanding of the action of cofilin in cells and for the design of new tools for controlling the action of cofilin in vitro and in vivo.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and related metabolic disorders.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history and a unique genetic structure. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that Madagascar is a mosaic of genetic contributions from Africa and Asia. The genetic structure is also influenced by geography, suggesting that the island is a unique place to study the history of human migration. The results also show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This is important for the study of the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. It also has implications for the study of the history of the rest of the world.

The ribosome is a complex machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequences that direct protein synthesis are not the only sequences that the ribosome reads. There are many other RNA sequences that the ribosome reads, and these sequences can have important effects on translation. In this work, we show that the presence of a chemical modification in mRNA sequences can have a significant impact on translation. We show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the ribosome can read mRNA sequences that are not directly involved in translation, and that these sequences can have important effects on translation. This work also highlights the importance of chemical modifications in mRNA sequences as a means of regulating translation.

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. These associations are robust to the influence of factors such as age, sex, educational attainment, and socioeconomic status. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in four of the five extant lineages of mammals that have invaded the water. The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the strict energetic constraints of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold, and the temperature of the nasal cavity is an important factor in the course of the disease. We show that the temperature of the nasal cavity influences the replication of rhinovirus in human airway cells.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the surface-associated type IV pili of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are used as a mechanochemical sensor to detect the mechanical activity of the cell surface. This results in a positive feedback loop that promotes the long-term attachment of the bacteria to the surface, and the activation of a large number of virulence factors. This study provides a new perspective on the role of pili in bacterial motility and virulence. It also opens up new avenues for understanding the evolution of bacterial sensing systems.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the past decades. This has led to a substantial increase in the number of pesticides in use, which has resulted in a higher risk of pesticide contamination of surface water. However, the extent of this contamination is not well known. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global situation, which shows that the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water is high. This is due to the fact that the number of pesticides in use is high, that many of them are toxic, and that many of them are new. Our results suggest that the risk of pesticide contamination of surface water is likely to increase in the future.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The origin of the virus and the lack of a vaccine have led to a global pandemic. The virus has also spread to animals, including deer, and the potential for spillover from animals to humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in deer, and the discovery of multiple human and deer lineages. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to prevent future spillover events and the emergence of new zoonotic diseases.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and is associated with a chronic, systemic immune response. However, the origin of this inflammation is not fully understood, and the role of the brain’s resident immune cells, microglia, in AD is still controversial. Here, we show that neurons, rather than microglia, are the major source of the proinflammatory factors that are associated with the earliest stages of AD. Our results suggest that the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) in the brain may be a key factor in the development of an immune response that is unique to neurons. This neuron-specific inflammatory response may be a critical component in the pathogenesis of AD.

This gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is an order of magnitude higher than that of plants. We also show that the biomass pyramid of the global marine ecosystem contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. These results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. They also provide a quantitative basis for understanding the impact of humans on the biosphere.

Here, we show that diamond can be demetallized, and its electronic properties can be tuned reversibly by applying strain. The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is even more so, as there are no known antifungal drugs. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide, and its antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. The antifungal activity of the peptide is shown to be due to its ability to bind to fungal cell walls and to induce reactive oxygen species. The antifungal activity of the peptide is shown to be effective against plant fungal pathogens, and the mode of action is shown to be effective against multiple fungal pathogens. The results of this study provide a foundation for the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction, and it is likely that the contributions of each sex are important to reproductive success. However, the extent of intersexual continuity is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and the female reproductive tract. We show that the female reproductive tract makes a substantial contribution to the sperm proteome, and we identify a number of female-derived proteins that are important for supporting sperm viability. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and the extent of intersexual continuity. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is essential for the normal function of platelets. It binds to the platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and promotes platelet aggregation. We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. The results also suggest that the second state of the receptor−ligand complex has a role in the normal function of VWF. This is the first demonstration of a mechanism for switching of a protein in the cell.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to identify a large number of virus–disease associations. This resource will be useful for future studies of the impact of viruses on human health, and will also be valuable for the study of the evolution of viruses.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the mechanisms of influenza virus-induced disease pathology and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus infection. The brain is thought to process language by first parsing it into words and then into phrases. However, there is no direct evidence that the brain performs these operations. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This pattern of activity is consistent with a model of the brain’s processing of language in which the words are first combined into phrases and then into sentences. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be important for understanding the brain’s processing of other complex sequences of information.

Axin is a key component of the canonical Wnt pathway, which is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a dual-functional protein that can act as a scaffold to inhibit the degradation of β-catenin or as a phosphatase to activate β-catenin. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which confers differential responsiveness to the two forms of Axin. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a deeper understanding of the molecular mechanism of redundant genes and their regulation. It also provides a new perspective for the study of the evolution of redundant genes.

We show that stimulation of LH neurons causes eating in a region of the LH that is not innervated by the ventral tegmental area. We also show that this region of the LH is innervated by neurons that project to the locus coeruleus, a region of the brain that is known to be involved in the regulation of feeding. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for future studies of the role of the LH in the regulation of feeding and the development of obesity.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected populations in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Climate change and air pollution are two of the most pressing global challenges. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. The global distribution of vaccines is uneven, and many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) lack access to vaccines. We report the design and synthesis of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2, which is well-suited for large-scale production of vaccines. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to the receptor angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) and is able to induce high antibody titers after a single dose. The variant is also able to protect hamsters from infection with two variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle further enhances the immune response. The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are expressed in the developing nervous system. They are implicated in the development of the nervous system in humans and in the regulation of the immune system in mice. In this study, we show that the small ALKAL proteins are ligands for the ALK/LTK receptor family in zebrafish and that they are involved in the development of the neural crest. This is the first demonstration of the involvement of the ALK/LTK receptor family in the development of the neural crest.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a much larger dataset to explore the diversity of this pathogen during this critical period of development. Our results show that the plague lineage that gave rise to the modern plague emerged from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor, and that the disease underwent a series of gene losses during its evolution. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, which suggests a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The findings also have implications for understanding the relationship between masculinity and political violence.

The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 1.1 billion ha of natural grassland worldwide. This has resulted in a massive release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, which is a major contributor to climate change. The management of agricultural lands can mitigate this C loss, but the most effective practices remain uncertain. We show that the management of grasslands with rotational grazing can increase soil C storage on Mollisols, a soil type that is widespread in the United States and globally. This highlights the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon and provides a promising strategy for climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and spread to humans. We used this framework to identify the top 12 wildlife viruses with the greatest spillover potential, which included SARS-CoV-2. The SpillOver platform is a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a tool for the global community to better understand and mitigate the threat of zoonotic viruses.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is an important factor in attracting pollinators, but the mechanisms by which plants produce colored nectar are not well understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also identify the enzymes responsible for the production of this pigment and show that these enzymes are necessary for the production of the red color. This work provides insight into the evolution of a convergent trait in two species of plants visited by both pollinators and vertebrates. This work also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of a color that is important for plant reproduction.

The genetic structure of Europe is a major topic of current research. However, the history of European population dynamics is much more complex and has been largely unknown. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in ribonucleic acids (RNAs). In this paper, we describe the development of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can replicate RNA, and, in the absence of proteins, can synthesize a variety of functional RNAs. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of the origins of life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and demographic characteristics of the residents of those neighborhoods. This may have important implications for the design of urban policy.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its high toxicity to cells limits its availability in nature. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of isocyanide-derived compounds suggests a role for these compounds in the regulation of copper homeostasis and in the control of interactions with competing microbes. The existence of the xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster in several filamentous fungi suggests that this is a widespread strategy for the control of copper availability and the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. The identification of this strategy in fungi provides a new perspective on the role of isocyanide-derived compounds in the control of interactions with microbes and may have implications for the control of copper homeostasis in animals. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of SiO2 that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The sedimentary rock is a possible source of the tridymite, plagioclase, magnetite, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment. The presence of opaline silica in the sedimentary rock is a possible product of diagenesis from high-SiO2 glass, as amorphous precipitated silica, or as a residue of acidic leaching in the sediment source region or at the site of deposition. The presence of post-lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate is consistent with the presence of sulfates in the modern environment of Gale crater.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to the warming climate. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

The Th17 cell lineage is central to the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental pathways that give rise to these cells are not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and the transcription factor T-bet, and that these cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating disease with no cure. The cause of ALS is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The disease is progressive and fatal, and there is no treatment that can slow or stop the disease. We have developed a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes, which can be expanded in culture. This allows us to study the disease in a dish and to test potential treatments. This will help us to understand the disease and to develop better treatments for ALS.

The role of the gut microbiota in the transmission of infectious agents to their vectors is an emerging area of research. Here, we show that the human granulocytic anaplasmosis bacterium, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the colonization of the vector. We demonstrate that iafgp binds the d-alanine terminus of bacterial peptidoglycan, which alters the permeability of the gut and the ability of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work also highlights the potential for the use of arthropod antibacterial proteins as a target for the development of novel insecticides. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important and enigmatic transitions in vertebrate evolution. The short-tailed bird group is a key group for understanding the origin of the modern avian body plan, but the diversity of early members of this group is limited. Here, we describe a new species of early pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This new species adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the evolution of the avian body plan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are involved. In this paper, we show that one of the processes that is important in the climate system is the increase in water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing temperature in the troposphere. This increase in water vapor in the stratosphere is a feedback that amplifies the climate response.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them are able to change their color. This phenomenon is called color polymorphism. In this study, we show that the occurrence of blue-green colors in vertebrates has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of proteins that bind biliverdin. We describe these proteins, hereafter named biliverdin-binding serpins (BBSs), and show that they are most similar to human glycoprotein alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. These findings provide insights into the evolution of color polymorphism in vertebrates and the function of serpins in general. They also have implications for the study of human diseases, such as alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer cells are able to survive in hypoxic conditions, which are characteristic of the tumor microenvironment. This study shows that hypoxia induces expression of the ALKBH5 demethylase, which increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is dependent on HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is also dependent on ALKBH5. This study provides a mechanism for how hypoxia induces the expression of breast cancer stem cells, which are responsible for the initiation of breast cancer metastasis. This knowledge may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was so thin that it was difficult to make a book that could be opened flat. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the event, the carbon cycle reorganization, and the timing of ecosystem recovery provide a unique window into the processes that led to the extinction and the subsequent recovery of the biosphere.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. IBD is a major health problem, and the current treatment is limited by the lack of effective therapeutic strategies. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system and for vaccine development. We have used cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein in the presence of the D614G mutation with the wild-type protein. We find that the mutant spike is more flexible and can adopt a range of more open conformations. These changes may facilitate binding to the receptor and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is new even for finite games. The proof also shows that the result holds for a large class of games with countably infinite players and action sets that are Borel sets. The result is also new in this setting. The proof is constructive, and it gives an algorithm for computing an ε-equilibrium.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. The chemical properties of atoms are of great importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in the search for new materials. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them are electron acceptors. We also show that the chemical properties of atoms can be predicted by our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is of great interest for the search for new materials under pressure. It also provides a new perspective on the chemical properties of atoms. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the global carbon cycle is uncertain. We show that changes in human demography, rather than climate, are the dominant driver of changes in global fire activity. This has the potential to reduce warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. However, the risk of more extreme fires and the implications for other ecosystem functions in fire-dependent ecosystems remain to be seen.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualisms. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the dynamics of a specific symbiont. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiosis, and that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night. These results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients may be a general strategy used by animals to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This could have important implications for the health of symbioses in nature.

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly being used to understand the world around us. However, the complexity of text data makes it difficult to identify patterns and to understand the meaning of the data. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We use this method to analyze a large corpus of narratives about violent deaths in the United States. We find that the corpus contains many latent topics that are not captured by existing structured variables. We also find that the topics are gendered and that the gender bias of the topics varies by topic. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains and can be extended to other types of data. It can also be used to identify the gender bias of topics. This method can be used to identify the gender bias of topics in other domains.

This period is often understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which it established itself in European rodents. Our study shows that the first introduction of the plague bacterium into Europe was not a one-time event, but rather repeated over a period of four centuries.
